translation: żołądź [an oval nut that grows on an oak tree and has an outer part shaped like a cup]
sentence: The acorns of the oak possess a considerable economic importance as food for swine.

translation: zadzior (też: docinek) [the sharp part of a fish hook or arrow that makes it difficult to remove from something caught on it; a remark that is funny but unkind]
sentence: He got a barb stuck in his foot. I tried to ignore their barbs about my new jacket.

translation: okazja [something on sale at a lower price than its true value]
sentence: I picked up a few good bargains at the sale.

translation: skinąć, przyzwać [to move your hand or head in a way that tells someone to come nearer]
sentence: The customs official beckoned the woman to his counter.

translation: dryg, talent [a natural skill or interest in something]
sentence: She has a bent for science.

translation: szumny, hałaśliwy, gwałtowny [(of people, animals, or behavior) noisy and full of life and energy]
sentence: The children and the dogs raced out of the house to give me a boisterous welcome.

translation: padlina [the body of a dead animal, especially a large one that is soon to be cut up as meat or eaten by wild animals]
sentence: Vultures flew around in the sky waiting to pick at the rotting carcass of the deer.

translation: krzepnąć, zastygać [to change from a liquid or soft state to a thick or solid state]
sentence: The blood had congealed in thick black clots.

translation: sporny, kontrowersyjny [causing, involving, or likely to cause disagreement and argument]
sentence: She has some very contentious views on education.

translation: korek [a short, cylinder-shaped piece of cork, plastic, or rubber that is put into the top of a bottle, especially a wine bottle, to close it]
sentence: I can't get the cork out of the bottle - can you try?

translation: korona kwiatu [all of the petals of a flower as a group]
sentence: The corolla has from five to nine petals, cohering at the base.

translation: martwy, zlikwidowany [formal; no longer existing, living, or working correctly]
sentence: He was a reporter for the defunct New York Herald newspaper.

translation: opustoszały [(of a place) with no people in it]
sentence: These resort towns are largely deserted in winter.

translation: desygnować, przeznaczać [formal; to choose someone officially to do a particular job; to say officially that a place or thing has a particular character or purpose]
sentence: The area has been designated as a nature reserve.

translation: pogardzać [to feel a strong dislike for someone or something because you think that that person or thing is bad or has no value]
sentence: She despised him for the way he treated her sister.

translation: pobożny [believing strongly in a religion and obeying all its rules or principles]
sentence: He was also very devout, and his morals were irreproachable.

translation: szerzyć, dyfundować [to (cause something to) spread in many directions]
sentence: Television is a powerful means of diffusing knowledge. Oxygen diffuses from the lungs into the bloodstream.

translation: pogarda, wzgarda [formal; the feeling of not liking someone or something and thinking that they do not deserve your interest or respect]
sentence: His disdain for politicians is obvious.

translation: konsternacja, niezadowolenie [a feeling of unhappiness and disappointment]
sentence: Aid workers were said to have been filled with dismay by the appalling conditions that the refugees were living in.

translation: spór [an argument or disagreement, especially an official one between, for example, workers and employers or two countries with a common border]
sentence: The unions are in dispute with management over pay.

translation: rozgoryczony, zgorzkiały [very angry about unfair things that have happened to you]
sentence: He died a disillusioned and embittered old man. They ignored all her pleas and she became very embittered.

translation: szpiegostwo [the discovering of secrets, especially political or military information of another country or the industrial information of a business]
sentence: Three people were also accused of engaging in espionage against a rival firm.

translation: przepiękny [very beautiful and delicate]
sentence: Her wedding dress was absolutely exquisite.

translation: głupio dowcipny [disapproving; not serious about a serious subject, in an attempt to be funny or to appear clever]
sentence: Stop being facetious; this is serious.

translation: niespokojny, przerywany [often stopping and starting and not happening in a regular or continuous way]
sentence: Her sleep was fitful, and he walked to the bed, standing beside it in the dark.

translation: wytrącić z równowagi [to make someone upset and confused, especially when they are trying to do something]
sentence: Don’t let that new tax form fluster you – it’s not as bad as it looks.

translation: ciągłe zmiany [continuous change]
sentence: The housing market is still in a state of flux.

translation: jaskrawy, krzykliwy [very brightly colored in an unpleasant way]
sentence: The coffee shop, painted a garish pink, is a landmark in the neighborhood.

translation: lodowaty [extremely cold]
sentence: The dining room was glacial.

translation: wyczerpujący [extremely tiring and difficult, and demanding great effort and determination]
sentence: Runners are taking part in a grueling 100-mile race in the mountains above Los Angeles.

translation: chusteczka [a square piece of cloth or paper used for cleaning the nose or drying the eyes when they are wet with tears]
sentence: She took out her handkerchief and blew her nose loudly.

translation: dźwigać [to move something heavy using a lot of effort]
sentence: He heaved the bag onto his shoulder.

translation: porcja [an amount of food given to one person at one time]
sentence: She gave me a very large helping of pasta.

translation: tylne [at the back of an animal’s body]
sentence: Phil’s dog stands on her hind legs to greet me.

translation: zawias [a piece of metal that fastens the edge of a door, window, lid, etc. to something else and allows it to open or close]
sentence: We had to take the front door off its hinges to get our new sofa into the house.

translation: gościnność [the act of being friendly and welcoming to guests and visitors]
sentence: The local people showed me great hospitality.

translation: błagać [literary; to ask someone to do or not do something in a very sincere, emotional, and determined way]
sentence: She implored her parents not to send her away to school.

translation: wzniecać, podburzać [to encourage someone to do or feel something unpleasant or violent]
sentence: She incited racial hatred by distributing anti-Semitic leaflets.

translation: zawiły [having a lot of small parts that are arranged in a complicated or delicate way]
sentence: The watch mechanism is extremely intricate and very difficult to repair.

translation: lokaj [disapproving; a servant or someone who behaves like one by obeying someone else's orders or by doing unpleasant work for them]
sentence: He treats us all like his lackeys.

translation: skazany na dożywocie [informal; someone who has been punished by being put in prison for a very long time or until they die]
sentence: In the 1980s, 726 lifers were paroled.

translation: gadatliwy [formal; having the habit of talking a lot]
sentence: He sipped it with relish and soon became somewhat loquacious.

translation: naśladownictwo, imitacja [the action or skill of being able to copy the voice, movements, etc. of others]
sentence: Parrots specialize in vocal mimicry.

translation: mieszaniec [a dog whose parents are of different breeds]
sentence: And I like walking my dog, a very old mongrel.

translation: pętla [one end of a rope tied to form a circle that can be tightened round something such as a person's neck to hang them]
sentence: They put him on the back of a horse and looped a noose around his neck.

translation: nieprzyzwoity, obsceniczny [offensive, rude, or shocking, usually because of being too obviously related to sex or showing sex]
sentence: In the raid, police found several boxes of obscene DVDs.

translation: zażegnać, zlikwidować [formal; to remove a difficulty, especially so that action to deal with it becomes unnecessary]
sentence: A peaceful solution would obviate the need to send a UN military force.

translation: prześcigać, przewyższać [to be, or do something, better than someone else]
sentence: He always tries to outdo everybody else in the class.

translation: kamyk [a small smooth round stone, especially one found on a beach or in a river]
sentence: This part of the coast has pebble beaches.

translation: pobieżny, powierzchowny [formal; (of an action) done as a duty or habit, without real interest, attention, or feeling]
sentence: The guard glanced perfunctorily at her pass and let her through.

translation: zakłopotany [confused, because something is difficult to understand or solve]
sentence: The students looked perplexed, so the teacher tried to explain once again.

translation: szczypać [to press something, especially someone's skin, strongly between two hard things such as a finger and a thumb, usually causing pain]
sentence: My sister's always pinching me and it really hurts.

translation: przygwoździć, przycisnąć [to hold someone, especially by the arms, to prevent them from moving]
sentence: He was pinioned to the wall by two men while another one repeatedly punched him.

translation: chwyt, sztuczka [something that is done or said in order to get an advantage, often dishonestly]
sentence: There are various ploys we can use if necessary.

translation: obecnie [formal; now; at the present time]
sentence: Of 200 boats, only 20 are presently operational.

translation: pierwotny [formal; existing at or since the beginning of the world or the universe]
sentence: The planet Jupiter contains large amounts of the primordial gas and dust out of which the solar system was formed.

translation: odbijać się, rykoszetować [to bounce back after hitting something]
sentence: The ball rebounded off the rim and Schultz dunked it in.

translation: pogodzić [to find a way in which two situations or beliefs that are opposed to each other can agree and exist together]
sentence: It is sometimes difficult to reconcile science and religion.

translation: skrucha [the fact of showing that you are very sorry for something bad you have done in the past, and wish that you had not done it]
sentence: This was an extremely violent crime, for which the boy showed no repentance.

translation: grafik, harmonogram [a list of people's names, often with the jobs they have been given to do]
sentence: If you look on the duty roster, you'll see when you're working.

translation: rumiany [(of a person's face) looking red and healthy]
sentence: Her face was ruddy and healthy-looking.

translation: burczeć, dudnić [to make a continuous low sound]
sentence: Please excuse my stomach rumbling - I haven't eaten all day.

translation: podstęp, fortel [a trick intended to deceive someone]
sentence: It was just a ruse to distract her while his partner took the money.

translation: skwierczeć [to make a sound like food cooking in hot fat]
sentence: The sausages are sizzling in the pan.

translation: lutować [to join pieces of metal together using solder]
sentence: These wires must be soldered to the pins.

translation: szumieć [literary; (especially of the wind or sea) to make a long high or low sound while moving]
sentence: The wind soughed through the towering pines nearby.

translation: iskra [a very small piece of fire that flies out from something that is burning, or one that is made by rubbing two hard things together, or a flash of light made by electricity]
sentence: Sparks were flying out of the bonfire and blowing everywhere.

translation: trwonić [to waste money or supplies, or to waste opportunities by not using them to your advantage]
sentence: They'll quite happily squander a whole year's savings on two weeks in the sun.

translation: wiercić się [to move from side to side in an awkward way, sometimes because of nervousness, embarrassment, or pain]
sentence: Nobody spoke for at least five minutes and Rachel squirmed in her chair with embarrassment.

translation: lojalny, oddany [loyal, especially for a long time; able to be trusted]
sentence: She has been a stalwart supporter of the party for many years.

translation: ogłupiać, otępiać [to make someone unable to think clearly, usually because they are extremely tired or have taken drugs]
sentence: He was stupefied by the amount they had spent.

translation: podrzędny, podporządkowany [having a lower or less important position]
sentence: The individual's needs are subordinate to those of the group.

translation: obejmować, wchłaniać [formal; to include something or someone as part of a larger group]
sentence: Soldiers from many different countries have been subsumed into the United Nations peace-keeping force.

translation: gobelin, arras [a picture or pattern that is made by weaving colored wool onto heavy cloth; the art of doing this]
sentence: There were rich vases as tall as a man and tapestries hung from the rough stone.

translation: skroń [the area on each side of your head in front of the top of your ear]
sentence: The vein at his temple throbbed angrily.

translation: dręczyć, udręczać [to cause a person or animal to suffer or worry]
sentence: The animals are tormented mercilessly by flies and mosquitoes.

translation: prześwitujący [allowing light to pass through but not transparent]
sentence: The sky was a pale translucent blue. The vase was made from translucent, milky glass.

translation: trwoga [formal; fear or worry about what is going to happen]
sentence: We view future developments with some trepidation.

translation: welon [a piece of thin material worn by women to cover the face or head]
sentence: After the ceremony, the bride lifted up her veil to kiss her husband.

translation: więdnąć [(of a plant) to become weak and begin to bend towards the ground, or (of a person) to become weaker, tired, or less confident]
sentence: Cut flowers will soon wilt without water.
